div.p: If you use Git for source code control, you can publish your app directly from a local Git repository to a web site. Git is a free, open-source, distributed version control system that handles small to very large projects. To use Git with your web site, you must first set up Git publishing for the web site. Use Set up Git publishing on Quick Start or the dashboard. After you set up Git publishing, each Git push initiates a new deployment. You'll manage your Git deployments on the Deployments page.

li.p: Create a web site in Web Sites. ( New - Web Site)
On Quick Start or the dashboard, click Set up Git publishing.
Follow the instructions to select a user name and password to use with Git, if you havenâ€™t done that already. A Git repository will be created for you in Web Sites.

tr.td: Forgot your password? To update your publishing credentials for Git and FTP, use Reset deployment credentials on the dashboard.

If you enable source control publishing from Git, you should perform all updates using the source-control solution that you used to deploy your web site. When you enable source-control publishing, a Deployments page is added to the Management Portal. The new page displays deployment history from Git, but will not include deployments from package uploads or developer tools. If you update your web site using one of those other methods while GIT publishing is enabled, the new deployment replaces the active deployment from Git. However, on the Deployments page, the active deployment indicator will not accurately reflect what is actually deployed.
